items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond will be 4.88mAOD at 16:45 on 28/04/2021.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 38 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 28/04/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.
   
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.

Although levels have declined during the last few weeks, we expect levels to remain high and low lying land and roads therefore remain at risk of flooding.
  
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 
 
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 5 May or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Newmarket
items.message: Groundwater levels at our Snailwell Borehole remain high but are slowly falling. Consequently there is an increased risk of groundwater flooding. We expect flooding to affect areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. No significant rainfall is currently forecast, however there is a risk that the groundwater levels will continue to remain high over the next week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message is updated weekly due to the slow reaction and will be updated Wednesday 28th April, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Porlock Weir with sea spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds. First forecast high water is 20:07 on 27/04/2021 with a level of 6.70 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 08:27 on 28/04/2021 with a level of 6.82 mAOD and a Force 5 North-Easterly wind.
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible at these times and conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Strong onshore winds will cause tide levels to rise further. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates where appropriate and checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high spring tides between 18:30 and 20:30, today, Wednesday 28th April. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads, particularly around Southfield Farm and Spurn Road. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated this evening, Wednesday 28th April, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Minehead due to high spring tides and strong winds. First forecast high water is 08:27 on 28/04/2021 with a level of 6.82 mAOD and a Force 5 North-Easterly wind. Second forecast high water is 20:49 on 28/04/2021 with a level of 6.67 mAOD and a Force 7 North-Easterly wind. All times are local and refer to Hinkley Point high water time. mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables.
Flooding to farmland is possible at these times, conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Flooding is possible for the coastal and tidal areas at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour. Conditions are forecast to ease for Thursday morning's high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our response team are closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tides on Tuesday 27th, Wednesday 28th and Thursday 29th April due to high spring tides. Water levels will be raised between the period of 05:00 tomorrow, 27th April and 19:45 on Thursday, 29th April. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect  coastal and tidal areas between Hartland Point and Lynmouth, including the Taw Torridge Estuary. 
 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the highest forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is at 06:30 on Wednesday at 5.09m AOD.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: The flood warning for the North Sea Coast at Hornsea remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high spring tides between 18:00 and 19:00, today, Wednesday 28th April. Areas most at risk are properties from Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated this evening, Wednesday 28th April, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The Flood Alert for the North Sea Coast at Skipsea, Hornsea, and Mappleton remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high spring tides between 18:00 and 19:00, today,  Wednesday 28th April. Areas most at risk are seafront areas, low lying land and roads in Hornsea. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated this evening, Wednesday 28th April, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: Waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides. Flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 28th April between 10:30 and 14:30. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Roosebeck, South Ulverston, Canal Foot, Crake estuary, Rusland Valley, Leven estuary, Eea estuary, Flookburgh, East Plain Farm, Grange-over-Sands, Meathop, Kent estuary, Milnthorpe, B5282 coast road, Sandside and Arnside. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. It is forecast that the high tides at midnight tonight and Thursday lunchtime will also reach the Flood Alert threshold. This message will be updated later today, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: High spring tides are forecast over the coming days. Forecast high water is 20:15 on 27/04/21 with a level of 7.61 mAOD and a Force 2 North Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 08:30 on 28/04/21 with a level of 7.73 mAOD and a Force 5 North Easterly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. Properties are unlikely to flood at this point but tides are rising and we will be updating this flood alert for the remainder of the week. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Wednesday 28/04/2021.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
The high tide is expected to be higher than usual as a result of high tides. Consequently flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is possible from 12:15pm today 28/04/21.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry between 12:15pm and 13:00pm , with a peak of 6.26m, Eastford Road between 12:30pm  and 13:45pm, with a peak of 6.41m, and Arpley Bridge between 12:45pm and 13:30pm, with a peak of 6.46m. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. Based on current forecast, the next high tide is not expected to reach flood alert threshold, however, the midday tide tomorrow 29/04/21 is expected to reach the flood alert threshold. We will issue further updates to this message as necessary.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Brockweir as a result of high spring tides. Tides will be at their highest between 8pm and 10pm this evening, 28/04/21. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however, conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  A series of high tides is due over the next 24 hours. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
The tide peaked Wednesday morning, 28/04/21 at Avonmouth Portbury at 7.79m & Newport at 7.41m.
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 8m at 9:15pm on 28/04, Newport 7.3 to 7.5m at 9:15pm on 28/04.   
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads along the estuary which may be flooded at high tide.  
This message will be updated  by 11pm on 28/04/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:45am and 3:45pm today, Wednesday 28th April. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.72mAOD at 1:45pm today, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind force 5, North Easterly. (mAOD is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables).  You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast.  We will continue to monitor the situation, and will reissue this message for any subsequent tides if required.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 19:30 and 20:30 Wednesday, 28/04/21. Flooding to the promenade and seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect Hunstanton seafront. The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
  
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 4.64 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.00 m. The forecast tide level is 4.64 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is north east. The forecast wind strength is Force 6

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: The flood alert for the River Hull Central catchment has been removed following the high tide on Tuesday evening, 27/04/2021. We are working to resolve an operational issue at the Hull Tidal Barrier. The high tide tomorrow morning, 28/04/2021, will be lower than Tuesday evening's tide, and will be within the normal range. We do not anticipate any flooding issues from tomorrow morning's tide.  This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Hull

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower River Hull has been removed following the high tide on Tuesday evening, 27/04/2021. We are working to resolve an operational issue at the Hull Tidal Barrier. The high tide tomorrow morning, 28/04/2021, will be lower than Tuesday evening's tide, and will be within the normal range. We do not anticipate any flooding issues from tomorrow morning's tide.  This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Flooding to the promenade and seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect King's Lynn, West Lynn, Clenchwarton, Terrington St Clement, Walpole Cross Keys and Tilney All Saints.   
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
  
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 4.64 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.00 m. The forecast tide level is 4.64 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is north east. The forecast wind strength is Force 6

Flooding to the promenade and seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Brockweir as a result of high spring tides. Tides will be at their highest between 8pm and 10pm today, 28/04/21. Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is possible at these times, however, conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  A series of high tides is due over the next 24 hours. High tides may impact properties and roads in and around Brockweir on the Wye Estuary. The tide peaked this morning, 28/04/21 at Avonmouth Portbury at 7.79m & Newport at 7.41m.
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 7.9m at 9:15pm on 28/04/21, Newport 7.3 to 7.5m at 9:15pm on 28/04/21. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths along the estuary, which may be flooded at high tide.  
This message will be updated  by 11pm on 28/04/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30am and 3:30pm today, Wednesday 28th April. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect high tide levels at Felixstowe Ferry waterfront and riverside areas at Woodbridge and Waldringfield. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.52mAOD at 1:30pm today, which is 0.29m above tide tables, wind force 5, North Easterly. (mAOD is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast.  We will continue to monitor the situation, and will reissue this message for any subsequent tides if required.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30am and 3:30pm today, Wednesday 28th April. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.52 mAOD at 1:30pm today, which is 0.29m above tide tables, wind force 5, North Easterly. (mAOD is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables).  You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast.  We will continue to monitor the situation, and will reissue this message for any subsequent tides if required.
